sen.j: 伊良子 道牛（いらこ どうぎゅう、寛文11年12月30日 (旧暦)（1672年1月29日） - 享保19年1月12日 (旧暦)（1734年2月15日））は、江戸時代の外科医。
sen.e: Dogyu IRAKO (January 29, 1672 – February 15, 1734) is a surgeon of the Edo period.
Dogyu IRAKO (January 29, 1672 – February 15, 1734) was a surgeon of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: be動詞をwasに変更しました。
sen.e: Dogyu IRAKO (January 29, 1672 – February 15, 1734) was a surgeon of the Edo period.

sen.j: 諱は好在、字は道牛、号 (称号)は無逸または見道斎。
sen.e: His imina (a personal name) was 好在, his family name was Dogyu, and his alias was 無逸 or 見道斎.
sen.cmt: 「好在」「無逸」「 見道斎」は読み方不明です。
sen.e: His imina (a personal name) was Kozai, his family name was Dogyu, and his alias was Muitsu or Kendosai.
sen.cmt: 確証はできていませんが、読み方を挿入しました。
sen.e: His imina (a personal name) was Kozai, his family name was Dogyu, and his alias was Muitsu or Kendosai.

sen.j: オランダ流の医学を学び、東洋医学と融合させた独自の医術を開発した。
sen.e: He studied Dutch-style medicine and developed his own medical science blended with Eastern medicine.
He studied Dutch-style medicine and developed his own medical science blended with Eastern medicine.

sen.j: 伊良子氏は甲斐源氏の支流といわれ、室町時代までは秋山氏を名乗る。
sen.e: The Irako clan is said to be a branch of the Kai-Genji clan and called themselves the Akiyama clan up to the Muromachi period.
The Irako clan is said to be a branch of the Kai-Genji clan and called themselves the Akiyama clan up to the Muromachi period.
The Irako clan is said to be a branch of the Kai-Genji clan and called themselves the Akiyama clan up to the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)の末に三河国渥美郡伊良子村（現在の愛知県田原市）に住んでいたため、伊良子姓に変更する。
sen.e: At the end of the Sengoku (Warring States) period (Japan) they lived in Irako Village, Atsumi County, Mikawa Province (present Tahara City of Aichi Prefecture), so they changed their family name to Irako.

At the end of the Sengoku (Warring States) period (Japan) they lived in Irako Village, Atsumi County, Mikawa Province (present Tahara City of Aichi Prefecture), so they changed their family name to IRAKO.
sen.cmt: 最後はIRAKOと大文字表記に変更しました。
sen.e: At the end of the Sengoku (Warring States) period (Japan) they lived in Irako Village, Atsumi County, Mikawa Province (present Tahara City of Aichi Prefecture), so they changed their family name to IRAKO.

sen.j: その後、伊良子一族は出羽国に移住して最上氏の家臣となり、伊良子宗牛・伊良子弾正ら、最上家の重臣を輩出した。
sen.e: Thereafter, the Irako family moved to Dewa Province and became vassals of the Mogami clan, producing many senior vassals of the clan such as 宗牛 IRAKO and Danjo IRAKO, and so on.
Thereafter, the IRAKO family moved to Dewa Province and became vassals of the Mogami clan, producing many senior vassals of the clan such as Sogyu IRAKO and Danjo IRAKO, and so on.
sen.cmt: 初めのIrakoを大文字表記にしました。名前を（そうぎゅう）と読みました。
sen.e: Thereafter, the IRAKO family moved to Dewa Province and became vassals of the Mogami clan, producing many senior vassals of the clan such as Sogyu IRAKO and Danjo IRAKO, and so on.

sen.j: 道牛の父・貞之助も最上義光の六男・大山光隆の家臣となるが、後に最上家の改易に遭遇し、主君の光隆も酒井忠世の預かりとなってしまう。
sen.e: Dogyu's father 貞之助 also became a vassal of Mitsutaka OYAMA, the sixth son of Yoshiaki MOGAMI, but later suffered kaieki (to forfeit rank of samurai and their properties) of the Mogami family, when his lord Mitsutaka was taken under custody of Tadayo SAKAI.
sen.cmt: 日外アソシエーツ(1983)『人物レファレンス事典I古代・中世編』によれば、「大山光隆」はMitsutaka OYAMAとなっています。「貞之助」の読み方不明です。
sen.e: Dogyu's father Sadanosuke also became a vassal of Mitsutaka OYAMA, the sixth son of Yoshiaki MOGAMI, but later suffered kaieki (to forfeit rank of samurai and their properties) of the Mogami family, when his lord Mitsutaka was taken under custody of Tadayo SAKAI.

Dogyu's father Sadanosuke also became a vassal of Mitsutaka OYAMA, the sixth son of Yoshiaki MOGAMI, but later suffered kaieki (to forfeit rank of samurai and their properties) of the Mogami family, when his lord Mitsutaka was taken under custody of Tadayo SAKAI.

sen.j: 浪人となった貞之助は、同じく熊本藩預かりとなった義光の弟・楯岡光直を頼って熊本に向かい、細川氏に仕官した。
sen.e: Becoming a ronin (a masterless samurai), 貞之助 headed for Kumamoto, relying on Yoshiaki's younger brother Mitsunao TATEOKA who had also been taken under custody of Kumamoto Domain, and served the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: 上記の日外アソシエーツ(1983)では「楯岡 光直」はMitsunao TATEOKAとなっています。
sen.e: Becoming a ronin (a masterless samurai), Sadanosuke headed for Kumamoto, relying on Yoshiaki's younger brother Mitsunao TATEOKA who had also been taken under custody of Kumamoto Domain, and served the Hosokawa clan.

sen.j: 西洋医学との出会い
sen.e: Encounter with Western medicine
Encounter with Western medicine
Encounter with Western medicine

sen.j: 父に従って九州に移り住んだ道牛は、当時唯一の西洋文明との接点であった長崎に近づいたこともあり、蘭学への憧憬に駆られる。
sen.e: Moving to Kyushu along with his father, Dogyu was driven into admiration for Western learning, partially because he came nearer to Nagasaki which was the only place to contact with Western civilization at that time.

Moving to Kyushu along with his father, Dogyu was driven into admiration for Western learning, partially because he came nearer to Nagasaki which was the only place to contact with Western civilization at that time.

Moving to Kyushu along with his father, Dogyu was driven into admiration for Western learning, partially because he came nearer to Nagasaki which was the only place to contact with Western civilization at that time.

sen.j: 貞享3年（1686年）、念願かなった道牛は長崎に赴き、オランダ商館付きの医官カスパル・スハンベルゲルが広めた、「カスパル流紅毛外科」を学ぶ機会を得る。
sen.e: Dogyu, fulfilled with his deepest desire, went to Nagasaki in 1686 and had an opportunity to learn 'Caspar-style red-haired surgery' which had been spread by Schamberger Ｃasｐar, a medical officer to the captain of the Dutch trading house.

sen.e: Dogyu, fulfilled with his deepest desire, went to Nagasaki in 1686 and had an opportunity to learn 'Caspar-style red-haired surgery' which had been spread by Schamberger CASPAR, a medical officer to the captain of the Dutch trading house.
sen.cmt: ＣＡＳＰＡＲと大文字表記に変更しました。
sen.e: Dogyu, fulfilled with his deepest desire, went to Nagasaki in 1686 and had an opportunity to learn 'Caspar-style red-haired surgery' which had been spread by Schamberger CASPAR, a medical officer to the captain of the Dutch trading house.

sen.j: このとき、道牛は16歳（数え）であった。
sen.e: Then Dogyu was 16 years old.
Then Dogyu was 16 years old.

sen.j: 東洋医学との融合~伊良子流外科の確立
sen.e: Establishment of 'Irako-style surgery' through blending with Eastern medicine

sen.j: その後、道牛は長崎で学んだ西洋医学と、日本に古来より伝わる東洋医学の長所を巧く融合させ、和洋折衷の独自の外科学を確立させる。
sen.e: Thereafter, Dogyu established his own semi-Western-style surgery in which advantages of Western medicine he studied in Nagasaki and Eastern medicine which had been handed down since ancient times in Japan were successfully blended.

Thereafter, Dogyu established his own semi-Western-style surgery in which advantages of Western medicine he studied in Nagasaki and Eastern medicine which had been handed down since ancient times in Japan were successfully blended.

Thereafter, Dogyu established his own semi-Western-style surgery in which advantages of Western medicine he studied in Nagasaki and Eastern medicine which had been handed down since ancient times in Japan were successfully blended.

sen.j: 元禄14年（1701年）、山城国紀伊郡伏見（現在の京都市伏見区）に移住した道牛はこの地で開業した。
sen.e: Moving to Fushimi, Kii County, Yamashiro Province (present Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City), Dogyu opened a medical practice there in 1701.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処：原文では「開業したが、」となって、下の文がつながっていましたが、複雑になりますので二文に分けました。

sen.j: 漢方・蘭方ともに適切な処方をしたその治療に名声が集まり、洛中洛外を始め近隣の諸国からも患者が集まったといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that he earned such fame for his proper treatment both in traditional Chinese medicine and Western medicine that patients gathered not only inside and outside Kyoto but also neighboring provinces.

sen.j: 享保19年1月12日（旧暦）、病を得ていた道牛は64歳でこの世を去る。
sen.e: On February 15, 1734, Dogyu, as he had been ill, passed away at the age of 64.
On February 15, 1734, Dogyu, as he had been ill, passed away at the age of 64.
On February 15, 1734, Dogyu, as he had been ill, passed away at the age of 64.

sen.j: 墓は伏見桃山仙石谷の竜泉寺に建てられ、生前交友のあった伊藤東涯の撰文による墓碑銘が彫られていたが、明治時代に奈良線敷設に伴って廃却され、現存しない。
sen.e: His tomb was built in 竜泉-ji Temple, Momoyama 仙石谷, Fushimi Ward, whose tombstone had epitaph chosen by Togai ITO who had been close to him while alive, but it was destroyed due to construction of Nara Railway Line in the Meiji period and does not exist now.
sen.cmt: 「仙石谷の竜泉寺」の読み方不明です。Sengokudani と Ryosen-ji Temple でしょうか。
sen.e: His tomb was built in Ryusen-ji Temple, Momoyama Sengokudani, Fushimi Ward, whose tombstone had epitaph chosen by Togai ITO who had been close to him while alive, but it was destroyed due to construction of Nara Railway Line in the Meiji period and does not exist now.
sen.cmt: （りゅうせんじ）、（せんごくだに）と読みました。

sen.j: 道牛は、最初の妻の森村某との間に二男一女を設けたがみな早世し、後添いとなった山川キヨとの間に生まれた好門がその後を継いだ。
sen.e: Although Dogyu had two sons and one daughter between his first wife, a certain Morimura, all of them died young and were succeeded by 好門 who had been born between Kiyo Yamakawa, his second wife.

Although Dogyu had two sons and one daughter between his first wife, a certain MORIMURA, all of them died young and were succeeded by Yoshikado who had been born between Kiyo YAMAGAWA, his second wife.
sen.cmt: （よしかど）と読みました。森村、山川を大文字で表記しました。
sen.e: Although Dogyu had two sons and one daughter between his first wife, a certain MORIMURA, all of them died young and were succeeded by Yoshikado who had been born between Kiyo YAMAGAWA, his second wife.

sen.j: 好門の子・伊良子光顕は滝口武者に列し、正六位下長門守の官位を与えられた。
sen.e: Mitsuaki IRAKO, 好門's son, ranked among Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence) and granted an official rank of Shorokuinoge (Senior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no Kami (a deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).

Mitsuaki IRAKO, a son of Yoshikado, ranked among Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence) and granted an official rank of Shorokuinoge (Senior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no Kami (a deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).
sen.cmt: a son of Yoshikadoと挿入しました。
sen.e: Mitsuaki IRAKO, a son of Yoshikado, ranked among Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence) and granted an official rank of Shorokuinoge (Senior Sixth Rank, Lower Grade) Nagato no Kami (a deputy minister in charge of regional administration in Nagato).

sen.j: さらに光顕の養子・光通は典薬寮に採用され、仁孝天皇の拝診を許された。
sen.e: Also Mitsuaki's adopted son 光通 was employed at Tenyakuryo (the Bureau of Medicine) and allowed to give Emperor Ninko medical examination.
Also Mitsuaki's adopted son Mitsumichi was employed at Tenyakuryo (the Bureau of Medicine) and allowed to give Emperor Ninko medical examination.
Also Mitsuaki's adopted son Mitsumichi was employed at Tenyakuryo (the Bureau of Medicine) and allowed to give Emperor Ninko medical examination.

sen.j: 光顕以後、伊良子家は二家（見道斎・千之堂）に系統が分かれるが、両家とも伊良子流外科を継承し、それぞれ伊良子光順・光信の時代に明治維新を迎えるまで、御典医として朝廷に仕えた。
sen.e: After Mitsuaki's days were over, the Irako family was divided in two family lines (見道斎 and 千之堂) but the both families succeeded to Irako-style surgery, and till they encountered the Meiji Restoration in the days of Mitsuoki IRAKO and Mitsunobu IRAKO, respectively, they had served chotei (the Imperial Court) as goteni (a doctor who is hired by bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun] or daimyo [a feudal lord]).
sen.cmt: 「見道斎」「千之堂」ともに読み方不明です。「光信」は用語集では「Mitsunobu?読み方確認できず」となっています。
sen.e: After Mitsuaki's days were over, the Irako family was divided in two family lines (Kendosai and Sen no do) but the both families succeeded to Irako-style surgery, and till they encountered the Meiji Restoration in the days of Mitsuoki IRAKO and Mitsunobu IRAKO, respectively, they had served chotei (the Imperial Court) as goteni (a doctor who is hired by bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun] or daimyo [a feudal lord]).
sen.cmt: (けんどうさい）、（せんのどう）と読みました。

sen.j: また、道牛の下には患者だけでなく門人も多く集い、そのうちの一人・大和見水は、後に華岡青洲の師となる。
sen.e: Besides, not only patients but also many pupils, one of which 見水 YAMATO later became a mentor of Seishu HANAOKA, gathered around Dogyu.

sen.j: つまり、青洲は道牛の孫弟子に相当する。
